title: Quantity - much, many, any - 1
instructions: Complete the sentences with B1manyB2, B1muchB2 or B1anyB2.

remarks: Corr: much. The word 'money' is uncountable and we can't use 'any' because we do have some money.

sentence: sandwiches. They weren't hungry at all.
remarks: Corr: any. As 'they weren't hungry', they at no sandwiches, so only 'any' is correct.

sentence: friends, or just Tom and Linda?
remarks: Corr: many. It's a question and a countable noun: 'friends', so only 'many' is correct.

sentence: I know nothing about George. I don't have
remarks: Corr: any. As I know nothing about George, only 'any' is correct.

sentence: bread at home. Let's go shopping.
remarks: Corr: any or much. If we have no bread at all, 'any' is correct. If we have just little bread at home, then 'much' is correct.

sentence: coffee a day, just two cups.
remarks: Corr: much. The word 'coffee' is uncountable, so 'many' is not correct. We don't want to say that we don't drink coffee at all, because we drink 'two cups', so 'any' is not correct either.

sentence: TV. I don't even have a TV set.'
remarks: Corr: much or any. The question is about an action so 'many' is not correct. It's not about a countable noun.
Corr: any. The speaker watches no TV at all, so 'any' is correct only.

sentence: time to boot up. 8 seconds is enough.
remarks: Corr: much. The word 'time' is uncountable and we can't say the PC needs no time at all, because it does need 8 seconds, so only 'much' is correct.

sentence: money did you win on poker last night?' 'I didn't win
remarks: Corr: much. The word 'money' is uncountable, so only 'much' is correct.
Corr: any. As the speaker didn't win any money at all, only 'any' is correct here.

sentence: sugar in this tea?' 'No, there isn't
sugar in it. I put sweetener in it.'
remarks: Corr: much or any. If we think there's some sugar in the tea and we ask about its quantity, 'much' is correct. If we ask in general, 'any' is correct.
Corr: any. The speaker put no sugar in the tea.
